dc:description: SKI was first reported in relation to Shprintzen-Goldberg syndrome (SGS) as early as 2012 (Doyle et al., Carmignac et al.; PMIDs: 23023332, 23103230). Clinical phenotypes of SGS include craniosynostosis and craniofacial features, motor and cognitive delays, mild-moderate intellectual disability, hypotonia, musculoskeletal anomalies, and cardiovascular problems such as aortic aneurysm. Variants in SKI have been identified in at least 40 probands with SGS (GeneReviews, Greally, 2020). Seven variants (missense and in-frame indel) reported in 13 probands in 4 publications (PMID: 23023332, 23103230, 24357594, 4736733) are included in this curation. Additionally, there is evidence that variants affecting amino acid position p.Thr180 may lead to phenotypes including thoracic aortic aneurysm and a marfanoid body habitus without intellectual disability, a feature which is often characteristic of SGS (PMID: 31980905). More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. The mechanism of pathogenicity is proposed to be dominant-negative (PMID: 23023332). Variants in SKI associated with SGS are concentrated in exon 1, a mutational hotspot, where variants exert a stabilizing effect on SKI protein function, attenuating the TGF-β signaling pathway (PMID: 33416497). This gene-disease association is also supported by experimental evidence including expression studies, animal models, and in vitro functional assays (PMID: 10906458, 23023332). In summary, SKI is definitively associated with Shprintzen-Goldberg syndrome. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This curation was approved by the ClinGen Craniofacial Malformations Gene Curation Expert Panel on 10/29/20 (SOP Version 8). The evidence summary was updated by the Heritable Thoracic Aortic Aneurysm and Dissection subgroup of the Hereditary Cardiovascular Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel on 7/23/2024.

evidence.dc:description: The Skeletal CDWG determined that 0.5 points are appropriate as a default score for missense variants when probands have detailed clinical phenotyping including radiographs/photographs, + 0.5 points for de novo occurrence = 1 pt.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 3
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: arachnodactyly, joint contractures, foot malposition, scaphocephaly or dolicocephaly, hypertelorism, downslanting palpebral fissures, intellectual disability, mypopia

evidence.dc:description: Family does not meet criteria in SOP (there are 3 affected individuals but two are identical twins).
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 4

member.rdfs:label: Family 4, II:3
member.phenotypeFreeText: craniosynostosis, arachnodactyly, pectus deformity, scoliosis, joint contracture (no generic enough HPO term), foot malposition, scaphocephaly or dolicocephaly, hypertelorism, downslanting palpebral fissures, micrognathia or retrognathia, intellectual disability, hernias, loss of subcutaneous fat, myopia
member.previousTestingDescription: Direct sequencing and multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification of FBN1, TGFBR1, and TGFBR2, and screened for chromosomal rearrangements by 180K or 244K Agilent array CGH.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: craniosynostosis, arachnodactyly, pectus deformity, scoliosis, joint contracture (no generic enough HPO term), foot malposition, scaphocephaly or dolicocephaly, hypertelorism, downslanting palpebral fissures, micrognathia or retrognathia, intellectual disability, hernias

Included in the original GGCEP curation, but not scored by the Craniofacial Malformations GCEP.
SKI is robustly expressed in the vessel wall in the proximal ascending aorta of wild type mice, as shown by immunolocalization.
evidence.rdfs:label: Expressed in aorta

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded for zebrafish model

In zebrafish, whole-mount in situ hybridization showed that SKI paralogs were expressed in developing skeletal tissue, neural tissue, and other structures, beginning at 2.25 hpf. SkiA in particular was expressed in the anterior CNS, lens, otic vesicles, hatching gland, and developing pectoral fin bud.
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression in zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: Western blot analysis (using primary dermal fibroblasts derived from 2 SGS patients and 2 controls) showed excessive SMAD2/3 and ERK1/2 phosphorylation (pSMAD2/3 and pERK1/2) in patient cells compared to controls, both at baseline and after acute (30 minute) stimulation with exogenous TGF-β2. This implies a loss of suppression of TGF-β dependent signaling cascades in SGS cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression in patient cells

evidence.dc:description: Significant increase in mRNA expression for TGF-β dependent genes in patient SGS fibroblasts compared to controls, as shown by qPCR. This is in keeping with prior work showing that transcription of these genes is normally suppressed by SKI.
evidence.rdfs:label: Increased TGF-beta mRNA

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded for zebrafish model
Zebrafish morphants recapitulate features of the SGS craniofacial phenotype and imply that there is a requirement for SKI in early cardiovascular development.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish model
